column1: Manado (Indonesian pronunciation: [maˈnado]) is the capital city of the Indonesian province of North Sulawesi.  It is the second largest city in Sulawesi after Makassar
column4: distributed over a land area of 157 km2.  The Manado metropolitan area has a population of 1.2 million as of 2018.  The city is located adjacent to the Bay of Manado
column5: and is surrounded by a mountainous area.Manado is among Indonesia's top-five tourism priorities.  The city is served by Sam Ratulangi International Airport
column6: which has been directly connected to the Philippines
column8: and China.  Bunaken National Park is one of the city's most famous tourist attractions.  The city is also known for its Christian-majority population
column9: and has held the country's biggest Christmas celebration annually.  It is also recognised as one of the most tolerant and peaceful cities in Indonesia.

column1: The name Manado is derived from the  Sangir language word manaro
column2: meaning 'on the far coast' or 'in the distance'
column3: and originally referred to the further of two islands which can be seen from the mainland.  When the settlement on this island was relocated to the mainland
column4: the name Manado was brought with it
column5: after which the island itself became referred to as Manado Tua (Old Manado).  The name for Manado in the Sangir language is Manaro.

column1: The first mention of Manado comes from a world map by French cartographer Nicolas Desliens
column2: which shows the island of Manarow (today's Manado Tua).  Before Europeans arrived in North Sulawesi
column3: the area was under the rule of the Sultan of Ternate
column5: and introduced the Muslim religion among some of its inhabitants.  The Portuguese made the Sultan their vassal
column7: and establishing a factory in Wenang.

column2: the Spanish had already set themselves up in the Philippines and Minahasa was used to plant coffee that came from South America because of its rich soil.  Manado was further developed by Spain as a centre of commerce for the Chinese traders who traded the coffee in China.  With the help of native allies
column3: the Spanish took over the Portuguese fortress in Amurang in the 1550s
column4: and Spanish settlers also established a fort at Manado so that eventually Spain controlled all of the Minahasa.  It was in Manado where one of the first Indo-Eurasian (Mestizo) communities in the archipelago developed during the 16th century.  The first King of Manado (1630) named Muntu Untu was in fact the son of a Spanish Mestizo.

column1: Spain renounced her possessions in Minahasa by means of a treaty with the Portuguese in return for a payment of 350
column2: 000 ducats.  Minahasan natives made an alliance treaty with the Dutch
column3: and expelled the last of the Portuguese from Manado a few years later.

column1: The Dutch East India Company or Verenigde Oost Indische Compagnie (VOC) built a fortress in Manado named Fort Amsterdam in 1658.  As with regions in eastern Indonesia
column2: Manado has undergone Christianisation by Dutch missionaries
column3: including Riedel and John Gottlieb Schwarz.  The Dutch missionaries built the first Christian church in Manado called Oude Kerk (Old church)
column5: and is now called Gereja Sentrum.  HMS Dover captured Manado in June 1810.  The Javanese prince Diponegoro was exiled to Manado by the Dutch government in 1830 for leading a war of rebellion against the Dutch.  In 1859
column6: the English biologist Alfred Wallace visited Manado and praised the town for its beauty.

column2: the Apostolic Prefecture of Celebes was established in the city.  In 1961
column3: it was promoted as the Diocese of Manado.

column1: The Japanese captured Manado in the Battle of Manado in January 1942.  The city was heavily damaged by Allied bombing during World War II.

column2: the headquarters of the rebel movement Permesta was moved to Manado.  When Permesta confronted the central government with demands for political
column3: economic and regional reform
column4: Jakarta responded by bombing the city in February 1958

column1: Manado experiences tropical rainforest climate (Af) according to Köppen Climate Classification
column2: as there is no real dry season.  The wettest month is January
column3: with an annual precipitation of 465 millimetres (18.3 in)
column4: while the driest is September with an annual precipitation of 121 millimetres (4.8 in).  The abundance of total precipitation seems to be influenced by the monsoon.  As its location is near the equator
column5: the temperature seems constant throughout the year.  The hottest month is August with an average temperature of 26.6 °C (79.9 °F)
column6: while the coolest months are January and February with an average temperature of 25.4 °C (77.7 °F).  Unlike other cities in Indonesia
column7: the temperature seems to be cooler.
